code: @Manual{,   title = {bkmr: Bayesian Kernel Machine Regression},   author = {Jennifer F. Bobb},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.2.2, https://sngao.github.io/bkmr/},   url = {https://github.com/jenfb/bkmr}, }

what: Compute the posterior mean and variance of h at a new predictor values — ComputePostmeanHnew
title: Compute the posterior mean and variance of h at a new predictor values — ComputePostmeanHnew
text: Compute posterior mean variance h new predictor values

title: Compute the posterior mean and variance of h at a new predictor values — ComputePostmeanHnew
code: ComputePostmeanHnew(   fit,   y = NULL,   Z = NULL,   X = NULL,   Znew = NULL,   sel = NULL,   method = "approx" )

title: Compute the posterior mean and variance of h at a new predictor values — ComputePostmeanHnew
text: fit object containing results returned kmbayes function y vector outcome data length n. Z n--M matrix predictor variables included h function. row represents observation column represents predictor. X n--K matrix covariate data row represents observation column represents covariate. contain intercept column. Znew matrix new predictor values predict new h, row represents new observation. set NULL default using observed exposures Z. sel selects iterations MCMC sampler use inference; see details method method obtaining posterior summaries vector new points. Options "approx" "exact"; defaults "approx", faster particularly large datasets; see details

title: Compute the posterior mean and variance of h at a new predictor values — ComputePostmeanHnew
text: list length two containing posterior mean vector posterior variance matrix

title: Compute the posterior mean and variance of h at a new predictor values — ComputePostmeanHnew
text: method == "approx", argument sel defaults second half MCMC iterations. method == "exact", argument sel defaults keeping every 10 iterations dropping first 50% samples, results fewer 100 iterations, 100 iterations kept guided examples additional information, go https://jenfb.github.io/bkmr/overview.html

title: Compute the posterior mean and variance of h at a new predictor values — ComputePostmeanHnew
code: set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.01363 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.0236 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.03347 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.04442 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.05533 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.06635 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.07737 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.08861 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.09985 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.11108 secs elapsed)  med_vals <- apply(Z, 2, median) Znew <- matrix(med_vals, nrow = 1) h_true <- dat$HFun(Znew) h_est1 <- ComputePostmeanHnew(fitkm, Znew = Znew, method = "approx") h_est2 <- ComputePostmeanHnew(fitkm, Znew = Znew, method = "exact")

title: Extract summary statistics — ExtractEsts
text: Obtain summary statistics parameter BKMR fit

title: Extract summary statistics — ExtractEsts
code: ExtractEsts(fit, q = c(0.025, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.975), sel = NULL)

title: Extract summary statistics — ExtractEsts
text: fit object containing results returned kmbayes function q vector quantiles sel logical expression indicating samples keep; defaults keeping second half samples

title: Extract summary statistics — ExtractEsts
text: list component data frame containing summary statistics posterior distribution one parameters (vector parameters) estimated

title: Extract summary statistics — ExtractEsts
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.0087 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.01822 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02771 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.03746 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.0469 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.06352 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.07298 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.08251 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.09205 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.10163 secs elapsed)  ests <- ExtractEsts(fitkm) names(ests) #> [1] "sigsq.eps" "beta"      "lambda"    "r"         ests$beta #>          mean         sd   q_2.5     q_25     q_50     q_75   q_97.5 #> beta 1.889308 0.08175852 1.72388 1.839835 1.889967 1.941782 2.046596

what: Extract posterior inclusion probabilities (PIPs) from BKMR model fit — ExtractPIPs
title: Extract posterior inclusion probabilities (PIPs) from BKMR model fit — ExtractPIPs
text: Extract posterior inclusion probabilities (PIPs) Bayesian Kernel Machine Regression (BKMR) model fit

title: Extract posterior inclusion probabilities (PIPs) from BKMR model fit — ExtractPIPs
code: ExtractPIPs(fit, sel = NULL, z.names = NULL)

title: Extract posterior inclusion probabilities (PIPs) from BKMR model fit — ExtractPIPs
text: fit object containing results returned kmbayes function sel logical expression indicating samples keep; defaults keeping second half samples z.names optional argument providing names variables included h function.

title: Extract posterior inclusion probabilities (PIPs) from BKMR model fit — ExtractPIPs
text: data frame variable-specific PIPs BKMR fit component-wise variable selection, group-specific conditional (within-group) PIPs BKMR fit hierarchical variable selection.

title: Extract posterior inclusion probabilities (PIPs) from BKMR model fit — ExtractPIPs
text: guided examples, go https://jenfb.github.io/bkmr/overview.html

title: Extract posterior inclusion probabilities (PIPs) from BKMR model fit — ExtractPIPs
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00877 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.01831 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02783 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.03735 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.05358 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.06313 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.07269 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.08224 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.0918 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.10139 secs elapsed)  ExtractPIPs(fitkm) #>   variable  PIP #> 1       z1 1.00 #> 2       z2 1.00 #> 3       z3 0.00 #> 4       z4 0.28

title: Extract samples — ExtractSamps
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00879 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.01839 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02798 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.04452 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.05409 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.06371 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.07331 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.08291 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.09255 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.10213 secs elapsed)  samps <- ExtractSamps(fitkm)

title: Investigate prior — InvestigatePrior
text: Investigate impact r[m] parameters smoothness exposure-response function h(z[m]).

title: Investigate prior — InvestigatePrior
code: InvestigatePrior(   y,   Z,   X,   ngrid = 50,   q.seq = c(2, 1, 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, 1/16),   r.seq = NULL,   Drange = NULL,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Investigate prior — InvestigatePrior
text: y vector outcome data length n. Z n--M matrix predictor variables included h function. row represents observation column represents predictor. X n--K matrix covariate data row represents observation column represents covariate. contain intercept column. ngrid Number grid points plot exposure-response function q.seq Sequence values corresponding different degrees smoothness estimated exposure-response function. value q corresponds fractions range data decay correlation cor(h[],h[j]) two subjects 50%. r.seq sequence values fix r estimating exposure-response function Drange range z_m data apply values q.seq. specified, calculated maximum ranges z_1 z_M. verbose TRUE FALSE: flag indicating whether print screen exposure variable q value completed

title: Investigate prior — InvestigatePrior
text: list containing predicted values, residuals, estimated predictor-response function degree smoothness considered

title: Investigate prior — InvestigatePrior
text: guided examples, go https://jenfb.github.io/bkmr/overview.html

title: Investigate prior — InvestigatePrior
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  priorfits <- InvestigatePrior(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, q.seq = c(2, 1/2, 1/4, 1/16)) PlotPriorFits(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, fits = priorfits)

title: Calculate overall risk summaries — OverallRiskSummaries
text: Compare estimated h function predictors particular quantile second fixed quantile

title: Calculate overall risk summaries — OverallRiskSummaries
code: OverallRiskSummaries(   fit,   y = NULL,   Z = NULL,   X = NULL,   qs = seq(0.25, 0.75, by = 0.05),   q.fixed = 0.5,   method = "approx",   sel = NULL )

title: Calculate overall risk summaries — OverallRiskSummaries
text: fit object containing results returned kmbayes function y vector outcome data length n. Z n--M matrix predictor variables included h function. row represents observation column represents predictor. X n--K matrix covariate data row represents observation column represents covariate. contain intercept column. qs vector quantiles calculate overall risk summary q.fixed second quantile compare estimated h function method method obtaining posterior summaries vector new points. Options "approx" "exact"; defaults "approx", faster particularly large datasets; see details sel selects iterations MCMC sampler use inference; see details

title: Calculate overall risk summaries — OverallRiskSummaries
text: data frame containing (posterior mean) estimate posterior standard deviation overall risk measures

title: Calculate overall risk summaries — OverallRiskSummaries
text: method == "approx", argument sel defaults second half MCMC iterations. method == "exact", argument sel defaults keeping every 10 iterations dropping first 50% samples, results fewer 100 iterations, 100 iterations kept guided examples additional information, go https://jenfb.github.io/bkmr/overview.html

title: Calculate overall risk summaries — OverallRiskSummaries
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00903 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.0188 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02854 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.03819 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.04784 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.05747 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.06698 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.07656 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.09252 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.10209 secs elapsed)  risks.overall <- OverallRiskSummaries(fit = fitkm, qs = seq(0.25, 0.75, by = 0.05),  q.fixed = 0.5, method = "exact")

title: Plot of exposure-response function from univariate KMR fit — PlotPriorFits
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  priorfits <- InvestigatePrior(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, q.seq = c(2, 1/2, 1/4, 1/16)) PlotPriorFits(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, fits = priorfits)

what: Predict the exposure-response function at a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivar
title: Predict the exposure-response function at a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivar
text: Predict exposure-response function new grid points

title: Predict the exposure-response function at a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivar
code: PredictorResponseBivar(   fit,   y = NULL,   Z = NULL,   X = NULL,   z.pairs = NULL,   method = "approx",   ngrid = 50,   q.fixed = 0.5,   sel = NULL,   min.plot.dist = 0.5,   center = TRUE,   z.names = colnames(Z),   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Predict the exposure-response function at a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivar
text: fit object containing results returned kmbayes function y vector outcome data length n. Z n--M matrix predictor variables included h function. row represents observation column represents predictor. X n--K matrix covariate data row represents observation column represents covariate. contain intercept column. z.pairs data frame showing pairs predictors plot method method obtaining posterior summaries vector new points. Options "approx" "exact"; defaults "approx", faster particularly large datasets; see details ngrid number grid points dimension q.fixed vector quantiles fix remaining predictors Z sel logical expression indicating samples keep; defaults keeping second half samples min.plot.dist specifies minimum distance new grid point needs observed data point order compute prediction; points computed center flag whether scale exposure-response function mean zero z.names optional vector names columns z verbose TRUE FALSE: flag whether print intermediate output screen ... arguments pass prediction function

title: Predict the exposure-response function at a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivar
text: long data frame name first predictor, name second predictor, value first predictor, value second predictor, posterior mean estimate, posterior standard deviation estimated exposure response function

title: Predict the exposure-response function at a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivar
text: guided examples, go https://jenfb.github.io/bkmr/overview.html

title: Predict the exposure-response function at a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivar
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00888 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.01853 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02817 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.0378 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.04738 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.05693 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.07406 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.08366 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.09327 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.10288 secs elapsed)  ## Obtain predicted value on new grid of points for each pair of predictors ## Using only a 10-by-10 point grid to make example run quickly pred.resp.bivar <- PredictorResponseBivar(fit = fitkm, min.plot.dist = 1, ngrid = 10) #> Pair 1 out of 6 #> Pair 2 out of 6 #> Pair 3 out of 6 #> Pair 4 out of 6 #> Pair 5 out of 6 #> Pair 6 out of 6

what: Plot cross-sections of the bivariate predictor-response function — PredictorResponseBivarLevels
title: Plot cross-sections of the bivariate predictor-response function — PredictorResponseBivarLevels
text: Function plot h function particular variable different levels (quantiles) second variable

title: Plot cross-sections of the bivariate predictor-response function — PredictorResponseBivarLevels
code: PredictorResponseBivarLevels(   pred.resp.df,   Z = NULL,   qs = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75),   both_pairs = TRUE,   z.names = NULL )

title: Plot cross-sections of the bivariate predictor-response function — PredictorResponseBivarLevels
text: pred.resp.df object obtained running function PredictorResponseBivar Z n--M matrix predictor variables included h function. row represents observation column represents predictor. qs vector quantiles fix second variable both_pairs flag indicating whether, h(z1) plotted z2 fixed different levels, plotted reverse order well (h(z2) different levels z1) z.names optional vector names columns z

title: Plot cross-sections of the bivariate predictor-response function — PredictorResponseBivarLevels
text: long data frame name first predictor, name second predictor, value first predictor, quantile second predictor fixed, posterior mean estimate, posterior standard deviation estimated exposure response function

title: Plot cross-sections of the bivariate predictor-response function — PredictorResponseBivarLevels
text: guided examples, go https://jenfb.github.io/bkmr/overview.html

title: Plot cross-sections of the bivariate predictor-response function — PredictorResponseBivarLevels
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.0088 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.01841 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02795 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.03747 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.04693 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.05638 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.06584 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.07534 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.08484 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.09433 secs elapsed)  ## Obtain predicted value on new grid of points for each pair of predictors ## Using only a 10-by-10 point grid to make example run quickly pred.resp.bivar <- PredictorResponseBivar(fit = fitkm, min.plot.dist = 1, ngrid = 10) #> Pair 1 out of 6 #> Pair 2 out of 6 #> Pair 3 out of 6 #> Pair 4 out of 6 #> Pair 5 out of 6 #> Pair 6 out of 6 pred.resp.bivar.levels <- PredictorResponseBivarLevels(pred.resp.df = pred.resp.bivar,  Z = Z, qs = c(0.1, 0.5, 0.9))

title: Plot bivariate predictor-response function on a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivarPair
text: Plot bivariate predictor-response function new grid points

title: Plot bivariate predictor-response function on a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivarPair
code: PredictorResponseBivarPair(   fit,   y = NULL,   Z = NULL,   X = NULL,   whichz1 = 1,   whichz2 = 2,   whichz3 = NULL,   method = "approx",   prob = 0.5,   q.fixed = 0.5,   sel = NULL,   ngrid = 50,   min.plot.dist = 0.5,   center = TRUE,   ... )

title: Plot bivariate predictor-response function on a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivarPair
text: fit object containing results returned kmbayes function y vector outcome data length n. Z n--M matrix predictor variables included h function. row represents observation column represents predictor. X n--K matrix covariate data row represents observation column represents covariate. contain intercept column. whichz1 vector identifying first predictor (column Z) plotted whichz2 vector identifying second predictor (column Z) plotted whichz3 vector identifying third predictor set pre-specified fixed quantile (determined prob) method method obtaining posterior summaries vector new points. Options "approx" "exact"; defaults "approx", faster particularly large datasets; see details prob pre-specified quantile set third predictor (determined whichz3); defaults 0.5 (50th percentile) q.fixed vector quantiles fix remaining predictors Z sel logical expression indicating samples keep; defaults keeping second half samples ngrid number grid points cover range predictor (column Z) min.plot.dist specifies minimum distance new grid point needs observed data point order compute prediction; points computed center flag whether scale exposure-response function mean zero ... arguments pass prediction function

title: Plot bivariate predictor-response function on a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivarPair
text: data frame value first predictor, value second predictor, posterior mean estimate, posterior standard deviation

title: Plot bivariate predictor-response function on a new grid of points — PredictorResponseBivarPair
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00881 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.01849 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02818 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.03814 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.04798 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.0579 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.06765 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.07801 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.088 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.09788 secs elapsed)  ## Obtain predicted value on new grid of points ## Using only a 10-by-10 point grid to make example run quickly pred.resp.bivar12 <- PredictorResponseBivarPair(fit = fitkm, min.plot.dist = 1, ngrid = 10)

title: Plot univariate predictor-response function on a new grid of points — PredictorResponseUnivar
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00936 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.01963 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02985 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.03988 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.04984 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.05989 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.06987 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.07986 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.08999 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.10032 secs elapsed) pred.resp.univar <- PredictorResponseUnivar(fit = fitkm)

what: Obtain posterior samples of predictions at new points — SamplePred
title: Obtain posterior samples of predictions at new points — SamplePred
text: Obtains posterior samples E(Y) = h(Znew) + beta*Xnew g^{-1}[E(y)]

title: Obtain posterior samples of predictions at new points — SamplePred
code: SamplePred(   fit,   Znew = NULL,   Xnew = NULL,   Z = NULL,   X = NULL,   y = NULL,   sel = NULL,   type = c("link", "response"),   ... )

title: Obtain posterior samples of predictions at new points — SamplePred
text: fit object containing results returned kmbayes function Znew optional matrix new predictor values predict new h, row represents new observation. specified, defaults using observed Z values Xnew optional matrix new covariate values obtain predictions. specified, defaults using observed X values Z n--M matrix predictor variables included h function. row represents observation column represents predictor. X n--K matrix covariate data row represents observation column represents covariate. contain intercept column. y vector outcome data length n. sel vector selecting iterations BKMR fit retained inference. specified, default keeping every 10 iterations dropping first 50% samples, results fewer 100 iterations, 100 iterations kept type whether make predictions scale link response; relevant binomial outcome family ... arguments; currently used

title: Obtain posterior samples of predictions at new points — SamplePred
text: matrix posterior samples new points

title: Obtain posterior samples of predictions at new points — SamplePred
text: guided examples, go https://jenfb.github.io/bkmr/overview.html

title: Obtain posterior samples of predictions at new points — SamplePred
code: set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00888 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.01869 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02842 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.0381 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.04766 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.05721 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.06685 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.07656 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.08625 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.09596 secs elapsed)  med_vals <- apply(Z, 2, median) Znew <- matrix(med_vals, nrow = 1) h_true <- dat$HFun(Znew) set.seed(111) samps3 <- SamplePred(fitkm, Znew = Znew, Xnew = cbind(0)) head(samps3) #>           znew1 #> iter51 2.406482 #> iter52 1.934470 #> iter53 2.018921 #> iter54 1.440331 #> iter55 2.047760 #> iter56 1.907901

title: Simulate dataset — SimData
text: Simulate predictor, covariate, continuous outcome data

title: Simulate dataset — SimData
code: SimData(   n = 100,   M = 5,   sigsq.true = 0.5,   beta.true = 2,   hfun = 3,   Zgen = "norm",   ind = 1:2,   family = "gaussian" )

title: Simulate dataset — SimData
text: n Number observations M Number predictor variables generate sigsq.true Variance normally distributed residual error beta.true Coefficient covariate hfun integer 1 3 identifying predictor-response function generate Zgen Method generating matrix Z exposure variables, taking one values c("unif", "norm", "corr", "realistic") ind select predictor(s) included h function; many predictors can included depend h function used. family description error distribution link function used model. Currently implemented gaussian binomial families.

title: Simulate dataset — SimData
text: list containing parameter values generated variables simulated datasets

title: Simulate dataset — SimData
text: hfun = 1: nonlinear function first predictor hfun = 2: linear function first two predictors product term hfun = 3: nonlinear nonadditive function first two predictor variables

title: Simulate dataset — SimData
code: set.seed(5) dat <- SimData()

title: Single Variable Interaction Summaries — SingVarIntSummaries
text: Compare single-predictor health risks predictors Z fixed specific quantile predictors Z fixed second specific quantile.

title: Single Variable Interaction Summaries — SingVarIntSummaries
code: SingVarIntSummaries(   fit,   y = NULL,   Z = NULL,   X = NULL,   which.z = 1:ncol(Z),   qs.diff = c(0.25, 0.75),   qs.fixed = c(0.25, 0.75),   method = "approx",   sel = NULL,   z.names = colnames(Z),   ... )

title: Single Variable Interaction Summaries — SingVarIntSummaries
text: fit object containing results returned kmbayes function y vector outcome data length n. Z n--M matrix predictor variables included h function. row represents observation column represents predictor. X n--K matrix covariate data row represents observation column represents covariate. contain intercept column. .z vector indicating variables (columns Z) summary computed qs.diff vector indicating two quantiles compute single-predictor risk summary qs.fixed vector indicating two quantiles fix remaining exposures Z method method obtaining posterior summaries vector new points. Options "approx" "exact"; defaults "approx", faster particularly large datasets; see details sel logical expression indicating samples keep; defaults keeping second half samples z.names optional vector names columns z ... arguments pass prediction function

title: Single Variable Interaction Summaries — SingVarIntSummaries
text: data frame containing (posterior mean) estimate posterior standard deviation single-predictor risk measures

title: Single Variable Interaction Summaries — SingVarIntSummaries
text: method == "approx", argument sel defaults second half MCMC iterations. method == "exact", argument sel defaults keeping every 10 iterations dropping first 50% samples, results fewer 100 iterations, 100 iterations kept guided examples additional information, go https://jenfb.github.io/bkmr/overview.html

title: Single Variable Interaction Summaries — SingVarIntSummaries
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00874 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.0185 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02821 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.03784 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.04747 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.05704 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.0666 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.07615 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.08572 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.09742 secs elapsed)  risks.int <- SingVarIntSummaries(fit = fitkm, method = "exact")

title: Trace plot — TracePlot
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00899 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.02652 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.03623 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.04587 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.05548 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.06563 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.07518 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.08473 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.0942 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.10375 secs elapsed)  TracePlot(fit = fitkm, par = "beta")  TracePlot(fit = fitkm, par = "sigsq.eps")  TracePlot(fit = fitkm, par = "r", comp = 1)

what: Fit Bayesian kernel machine regression — kmbayes
title: Fit Bayesian kernel machine regression — kmbayes
text: Fits Bayesian kernel machine regression (BKMR) model using Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods.

title: Fit Bayesian kernel machine regression — kmbayes
code: kmbayes(   y,   Z,   X = NULL,   iter = 1000,   family = "gaussian",   id = NULL,   verbose = TRUE,   Znew = NULL,   starting.values = NULL,   control.params = NULL,   varsel = FALSE,   groups = NULL,   knots = NULL,   ztest = NULL,   rmethod = "varying",   est.h = FALSE )

title: Fit Bayesian kernel machine regression — kmbayes
text: y vector outcome data length n. Z n--M matrix predictor variables included h function. row represents observation column represents predictor. X n--K matrix covariate data row represents observation column represents covariate. contain intercept column. iter number iterations run sampler family description error distribution link function used model. Currently implemented gaussian binomial families. id optional vector (length n) grouping factors fitting model random intercept. NULL random intercept included. verbose TRUE FALSE: flag indicating whether print intermediate diagnostic information model fitting. Znew optional matrix new predictor values predict h, row represents new observation. slow model fitting, can done post-processing step using SamplePred starting.values list starting values parameter. specified default values chosen. control.params list parameters specifying prior distributions tuning parameters MCMC algorithm. specified default values chosen. varsel TRUE FALSE: indicator whether conduct variable selection Z variables h groups optional vector (length M) group indicators fitting hierarchical variable selection varsel=TRUE. varsel=TRUE without group specification, component-wise variable selections performed. knots optional matrix knot locations implementing Gaussian predictive process Banerjee et al. (2008). Currently implemented models without random intercept. ztest optional vector indicating variables Z conduct variable selection (remaining variables forced model). rmethod predictors forced h function, method sampling r[m] values. Takes value 'varying' allow separate r[m] predictor; 'equal' force r[m] predictor; 'fixed' fix r[m] starting values est.h TRUE FALSE: indicator whether sample posterior distribution subject-specific effects h_i within main sampler. slow model fitting.

title: Fit Bayesian kernel machine regression — kmbayes
text: object class "bkmrfit" (containing posterior samples model fit), associated methods: print (.e., print.bkmrfit) summary (.e., summary.bkmrfit)

title: Fit Bayesian kernel machine regression — kmbayes
text: Bobb, JF, Valeri L, Claus Henn B, Christiani DC, Wright RO, Mazumdar M, Godleski JJ, Coull BA (2015). Bayesian Kernel Machine Regression Estimating Health Effects Multi-Pollutant Mixtures. Biostatistics 16, . 3: 493-508. Banerjee S, Gelfand AE, Finley AO, Sang H (2008). Gaussian predictive process models large spatial data sets. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 70(4), 825-848.

code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00876 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.01842 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.02801 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.03751 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.04704 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.23671 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.24666 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.25633 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.26589 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.27548 secs elapsed) fitkm #> Fitted object of class 'bkmrfit' #> Iterations: 100  #> Outcome family: gaussian   #> Model fit on: 2023-12-06 17:14:53.038327

title: Summarizing BKMR model fits — summary.bkmrfit
text: object object class "bkmrfit" q quantiles posterior distribution show digits number digits show printing show_ests logical; TRUE, prints summary statistics posterior distribution show_MH logical; TRUE, prints acceptance rates Metropolis-Hastings algorithm ... arguments passed methods.

title: Summarizing BKMR model fits — summary.bkmrfit
text: return value, prints detailed summary fit console

title: Summarizing BKMR model fits — summary.bkmrfit
code: ## First generate dataset set.seed(111) dat <- SimData(n = 50, M = 4) y <- dat$y Z <- dat$Z X <- dat$X  ## Fit model with component-wise variable selection ## Using only 100 iterations to make example run quickly ## Typically should use a large number of iterations for inference set.seed(111) fitkm <- kmbayes(y = y, Z = Z, X = X, iter = 100, verbose = FALSE, varsel = TRUE) #> Iteration: 10 (10% completed; 0.00854 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 20 (20% completed; 0.02683 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 30 (30% completed; 0.03642 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 40 (40% completed; 0.04593 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 50 (50% completed; 0.05537 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 60 (60% completed; 0.06489 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 70 (70% completed; 0.07431 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 80 (80% completed; 0.08374 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 90 (90% completed; 0.09319 secs elapsed) #> Iteration: 100 (100% completed; 0.11047 secs elapsed) summary(fitkm) #> Fitted object of class 'bkmrfit' #> Iterations: 100  #> Outcome family: gaussian   #> Model fit on: 2023-12-06 17:14:53.338206  #> Running time:  0.11072 secs  #>  #> Acceptance rates for Metropolis-Hastings algorithm: #>               param      rate #> 1            lambda 0.1010101 #> 2 r/delta (overall) 0.5252525 #> 3 r/delta  (move 1) 0.3255814 #> 4 r/delta  (move 2) 0.6785714 #>  #> Parameter estimates (based on iterations 51-100): #>       param    mean      sd   q_2.5  q_97.5 #> 1      beta 1.88931 0.08176 1.72388 2.04660 #> 2 sigsq.eps 0.50905 0.10964 0.33635 0.74966 #> 3        r1 0.76502 0.13487 0.49609 0.94809 #> 4        r2 1.22987 0.08528 1.09164 1.36021 #> 5        r3 0.00000 0.00000 0.00000 0.00000 #> 6        r4 0.00606 0.01004 0.00000 0.02415 #> 7    lambda 4.56075 0.55773 4.17943 6.14513 #>  #> Posterior inclusion probabilities: #>   variable  PIP #> 1       z1 1.00 #> 2       z2 1.00 #> 3       z3 0.00 #> 4       z4 0.28 #> NULL

title: bkmr 0.2.2
text: CRAN release: 2022-03-28

title: bkmr 0.2.2
text: Corrected code produced warning length > 1 coercion logical Update functions use deprecated functions dplyr package

title: bkmr 0.2.2
text: longer export following functions: CalcGroupPIPs, CalcWithinGroupPIPs, CalcPIPs typically calculated using function ExtractPIPs ComputePostmeanHnew.approx ComputePostmeanHnew.exact typically calculated using function ComputePostmeanHnew set_verbose_opts called internally Expanded function documentation adding example code

title: bkmr 0.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2022-03-04

title: bkmr 0.2.1
text: allowable values starting parameter r[m] parameters updated follows longer truncated single value (varsel = FALSE rmethod = "varying") can equal 0 (varsel = TRUE) Error longer generated starting values h.hat positive checking class object, use inherits() instead class()

title: bkmr 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2017-03-24

title: bkmr 0.2.0
text: Added ability binomial outcome family implementing probit regression within kmbayes() Removed computation subject-specific effects h[] within kmbayes(), always desired, greatly slows model fitting still done setting option est.h = TRUE kmbayes function posterior samples h[] can now obtained via post-processing SamplePred function; alternatively, posterior summaries (mean, variance) can obtained via post-processing ComputePostmeanHnew function Added ability use exact estimates posterior mean variance specifying argument method = 'exact' within post-processing functions (e.g., OverallRiskSummaries(), PredictorResponseUnivar())

title: bkmr 0.2.0
text: Fixed PredictorResponseBivarLevels() argument both_pairs = TRUE (#4)
